bug.short_desc: Wiki has a 30-second lag on Firefox for an uncached page

long_desc.thetext:
Upon opening a wike page for the first time on any given day, the page loads 75% then has a 30-second lag. Subsequent pages are fast, until you clear your cache.
Funny thing is, by clearing my cache and fetching all 9-10 files individually one after the other (CSS, .js, html, images), not one of them lags.
When tailing the access_log, it seems to choke on this file: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php?title=MediaWiki:Eclipse.css&action=raw&ctype=text/css&smaxage=18000
However, I cannot get any lag from it by fetching it directly....
Could it be a concurrency/locking issue?

(In reply to comment #1) > Could it be a concurrency/locking issue? >
Hmmm... Hadn't thought of that. I knew there was a good reason for being nice to you...
I'll look into it, thanks.

As it turns out, the delay is caused by our needs for a load-balanced site.
PHP session information is stored in files on an NFS mount to preserve session information when transparently bouncing from one node to the other. Typically, this isn't a problem as the session information is touched only once per page, but in Wiki's case, it is touched every time index.php is accessed. Each page view loads index.php about four times: once for the page, twice for dynamic CSS and once for a dynamic JavaScript. As five simultaneous connections quickly come in for a single page, NFS stumbles over how to lock the session file. This also explains why there is no lag when accessing each of the required files for one page separately.
I see two practical solutions exist:
a) hack our "Eclipse" template to load CSS and Javascript information statically, reducing calls to index.php
b) hack MediaWiki to store PHP session information in MySQL, which provides much better locking.
I'll try a) as it's an easy approach; if it fails, then b).

I reduced the number of calls to index.php. I no longer get the 30-second lag by using the wiki normally. I *can* get the 30-second lag by holding the F5 (reload) key to generate multiple, simultaneous calls to index.php for the same session, but that's abuse; not normal usage.
Another thing that caught my attention while working from home is that, in order to support the https connection for authentication, wiki is not in the hi-priority bandwidth pool, so it will be as slow as the downloads area when we're saturated. This shouldn't be a big problem for a site like wiki as the requests are fairly small, but it does mean that with this setup, wiki will never be as fast as our website under heavy load.
We could move wiki into the QoS, but it would require a bit of effort. Let's give it a try for a few weeks, and if it's still slow, we'll move it into the QoS.

Should b) be required, this might help:
http://www.phpclasses.org/browse/package/1518.html
Closing as fixed - the Wiki is performing well. We must ensure that this lag does not reappear with the upgrade to the latest MediaWiki.

bug.short_desc: Eclipse causes kernel warnings and prevents Rosetta apps from launching

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061102-1715
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Load Eclipse 2. Load Rosetta application
More information: I am running Mac OS X 10.4.8 Intel. When running Eclipse, I see the following logs in my System.log:
lsf_map: unable to allocate mapping
These entries appear a few times a minute. Rosetta apps fail to start. Exiting Eclipse fixes the problem. This may not be an Eclipse bug per se, it may simply be triggering a kernel problem.
Actually, it appears that Eclipse just makes this worse, not actually causes the problem. There must be some resource that's at stake, and Eclipse grabs a lot of whatever it is.

bug.short_desc: Improve query tooltip layout

long_desc.thetext:
Current query tooltip layout look like this:
[icon] [server] (sunched: [sync time]) [multiline error details] Completed [x] of [x] (query max: [x]) [progress bar]
In this layout error details are not visually separated and hard to read. I suggest to change layout as following:
[progress bar] [icon] [server] (sunched: [sync time]) Completed [x] of [x] (query max: [x]) [multiline error details]
or
[icon] [server] (sunched: [sync time]) [progress bar] Completed [x] of [x] (query max: [x]) [multiline error details]

Please also add number of open issues, so it won't be necessary to substract 4 digit numbers to figure out how many open issues appear on query:
Open [x] / Completed [x] / Total [x]

bug.short_desc: VM Capabilities property page shows up unexpectedly

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M3
We support the Properties action on some of our objects (e.g. snapshots and baselines). Sometimes the Refactoring History property page shows up in addition to the one(s) that match our object.
In the plugin.xml for org.eclipse.ltk.refactoring.ui, it has: <extension point="org.eclipse.ui.propertyPages"> <page class="org.eclipse.ltk.internal.ui.refactoring.history.RefactoringPropertyPage" id="org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring.property.page" name="%RefactoringPropertyPage_name" > <keywordReference id="org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring.property.page"/> <enabledWhen> <test forcePluginActivation="false" property="org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring.refactoringPropertiesEnabled" value="true"> </test> </enabledWhen> </page> </extension>
Notice there's no objectClass= attribute.
The property tester is declared as: <extension point="org.eclipse.core.expressions.propertyTesters"> <propertyTester class="org.eclipse.ltk.internal.ui.refactoring.history.RefactoringPropertyPageTester" id="org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring.refactoringPropertiesTester" namespace="org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring" properties="refactoringPropertiesEnabled" type="org.eclipse.core.runtime.IAdaptable"> </propertyTester> </extension>
Note that it's targeting IAdaptable.
The property tester looks for an IResource adapter that's a project with a refactoring history store. Our objects in question do not adapt to IResource, so the tester returns false. But it's not always called, since property testers don't trigger plugin activation. The net result is that the Refactoring History property page shows up if JDT hasn't been started yet.
On startup, we sometimes see messages like: !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.expressions 4 201 2006-11-30 13:36:33.750 !MESSAGE No property tester contributes a property refactoringPropertiesEnabled to type class com.ibm.<snip>
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.expressions 4 201 2006-11-30 13:36:33.765 !MESSAGE No property tester contributes a property vmpage to type class com.ibm/<snip>
The vmpage property tester comes from JDT Debug UI for the VM Capabilities page. We don't get the VM Capabilities page showing up unexpectedly though, since it also has instanceof checks in the expression. Maybe the warning wouldn't happen if the instanceof checks came first.
(back link: #13065)

Actually the VM Capabilities page does show up unexpectedly for some of our objects (e.g. a repository connection). If selected, page creation fails and it shows an error message: "The selected debug element does not allow access to the underlying virtual machine."

The VM Capabilities page's extension is:
<page class="org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.propertypages.VMCapabilitiesPropertyPage" id="org.eclipse.debug.ui.properties.vmCapabilities" name="%vmCapabilitiesPageName" > <enabledWhen> <and> <test property="org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.vmpage"/> <or> <instanceof value="org.eclipse.debug.core.model.IDebugElement"> </instanceof> <instanceof value="org.eclipse.debug.core.model.IProcess"> </instanceof> </or> </and> </enabledWhen> </page>
I guess it short circuits before the instanceof checks if the plugin isn't started.
Maybe it shouldn't short-circuit in this case. <and not_activated false> should evaluate to false.

Alternatively, the VM Capabilities page could specify objectClass="org.eclipse.debug.core.model.IDebugElement" or objectClass="org.eclipse.debug.core.model.IProcess"
Not sure if there's a common denominator object that can be used for the Refactoring history case. Maybe objectClass="org.eclipse.core.resources.IProject" with adaptable=true?
The problem with the Refactoring History property page is bug 154735 and has been fixed in latest builds.

Moving to JDT Debug. I think we can improve the property tester to only use "debug platform" code - we can test if the debug element is from a java debug model (based on id), and if the process has an associated debug target with a java debug model id.

Created an attachment (id=55081) Patch for review
Patch removes the old VMCapabilitiesPageTester and references to it. A new property test was created in debug ui called DebugModelPropertyTester. The new test checks if the receiver is a IProcess or IDebugElement, determines the debug target, and checks if the target has a debug model id matching a passed argument. The VM Capability Page uses this new test for enablement, passing org.eclipse.jdt.debug as an argument.
Darin, please review the changes.

Comments:
* The "value" attribute of the property tester should be used instead of the "args" attribute, when passing an expected value to a property tester (i.e. the use of the property tester in jdt-debug-ui plug-in XML). As well, the property tester needs to be updated to check the expetedValue rather than the args. * The property tester currently only works when the debug element is terminated or disconneted. That's what we need in the case of the Java VM to display the proeprty page. However, as a general purpose property tester, we should not require the target to be terminated/disconnected to return a debug model identifier. To address this we could define two properties for the tester: debugModelId, and isTerminated. The isTerminated property would work for instances of ITerminate.

Created an attachment (id=55140) Patch
Set up the property tester to check two properties. "testDebugModelID" compares the debug model identifier of the receiver against the expected value passed as an argument. The "isTerminatedOrDisconnected" property checks if the receiver is terminated or disconnected.
Darin, please review the changes.
Applied patch with minor changes.
Verified.

bug.short_desc: problem parsing select statements

long_desc.thetext: The parser is having problems accepting some select statements.

Created an attachment (id=54832) includes new test cases
The patch includes more JUnit tests. There are test cases that illustrate the bug with select statements.

Created an attachment (id=54835) test cases for the lexer/parser
The previously attached patch only updates the JUnit classes to include the new tests, but does not include the test cases. This patch has all of the new test cases only (it was created at the 'parser-test-files' level in the package view).

The updated parser in the repository is partially fixed for select statements. however, select type statements still are not working. the parser incorrectly handles a 'type is' statement that uses an intrinsic type (e.g., type is(integer)).
More information on the failing 'select type' statements, including an example, is in bug #173230.
This bug has been fixed and a test case has been added to tests/bug-reports.

bug.short_desc: keywords used as identifiers not being accepted

long_desc.thetext:
The parser is not accepting valid code that uses keywords as identifiers. For example, the following code should be accepted:
a = result
end
Currently, the above code is causing the parser to fail.
Test cases that illustrate this bug are included in the patch attached to bug #166409.
This should now be fixed with the latest commit. Sale's algorithm was used and is performed as a lexical prepass to update the tokens that should be identifiers instead of keywords.

bug.short_desc: '::' appearing in array index specifier causes parser to fail

long_desc.thetext:
The parser is failing to accept valid code of the following form:
mydata(1::nr+1)
A test case that illustrates this bug is provided in the patch attached to bug #166409. It is note_7.44.f03 of the Chapter7 tests.
This bug is fixed and a test case has been added to tests/bug-reports.

bug.short_desc: Auto publish doesnt happen after eclipse starts

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: wtp1.5.2
Steps To Reproduce: 1. 2. 3. I have a server. I initialize the status of the server after I start eclipse. The state of the server is Republish. The auto publish is set to publish every 5 seconds, but the framework doesnt do any publish. Perhaps, it is due to there isnt any change in the workspace. But in this case, the server should show Synchronized instead of Republish.
My ref # 407043.
More information:
Agreed. Server should auto-publish after the server state is initialized, provided that the server is started.
Code dropped to head, will be released to 2.0 stream shortly.
Fix released to 2.0 builds.
Changing milestone to indicate that this fix was also backported into the 1.5.3 release stream.
Closing as fixed since WTP 1.5.3. Please reopen if closed in error.

bug.short_desc: default Automatic Publishing setting for a new server is to Override workspace defaults

long_desc.thetext:
wtp-sdk-I-I200611300401-200611300401.zip
With a fresh workspace, I set the Server preferences to Automatically publish to both local and remote servers using the default intervals. I then set up a new Apache Tomcat 5.5.16 runtime and created a corresponding Server instance. When I opened the server to edit it, the Automatic Publishing setting was set to Override the default with a 1 second interval. The initial setting should be to use the default settings.

Hmmm... Not sure how to handle this. Server adopter providers typically want their own defaults. For instance, Tomcat is set really low by default (because publishing should be fast), but a remote server should probably be set much higher. The type of server (and the kind of development you do with it) can also affect this.
Having a default per server type is overkill; forcing all servers to use the same default isn't going to work either. I'll need to think about this one, unless you have a suggestion.
Can you vary the generated default based on whether the server is local or remote?
Yes, any server that is overriding the defaults can do this, and I know of at least one server adapter that already is.
*** Bug 199519 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

After review and discussion, we've decided that there is no good way to have global publishing defaults. Every server is different - local vs remote, server types that support hotdeploy vs those that don't, etc. - and this affects what a good default publishing options and interval should be. Providing a default per server type or some of the different situations might be possible, but the UI would be incredibly complex for the average user.
In 3.0 M4 we've completely removed the default UI (although there are still basic underlying defaults) and each server type is responsible for setting an appropriate default when a server is created. Since removing the global options and improving the other UI has made this bug irrelevant, I am closing it.

bug.short_desc: Junit test failures in build: WTP 2.0 I-I200611300401

long_desc.thetext: http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/R2.0/I-I200611300401-200611300401/testResults/html/org.eclipse.jst.jsf.metadata.tests_.html
Cameorn fixed build.properties of the plugin, org.eclipse.jst.jsf.common
Closing as part of mass query to clean up old resolved bugs in untargetted milestones.

bug.short_desc: JVMTI Profiling agent error when BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR defined

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: TPTP 4.3 RC
Steps To Reproduce: 1.set BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR=C:\Program Files\Intel\VTune\analyzer\bin\ 2.java -agentlib:JPIBootLoader=JPIAgent:server=standalone;CGProf Hello Error occurred during initialization of VM agent library failed to init: JPIBootLoader
More information: org.eclipse.tptp.platform.jvmti.runtime\src-native\src\Martini\Infrastructure\LibraryLoader\LibraryLoader.cpp line 32 specifies the order that libraries should be searched. If one at one point in time had a VTune installed that defined BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR, it takes precedence over JAVA_PROFILER_HOME and JPI.dll won't load.
Resolution: remove BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR from your environment (upgrading Vtune if necessary)... [This bit me on one of my windows systems and was fine on another of my systems]. I'm not 100% sure if it was from an old VTune or from an old version of Martini that I once had on my laptop.
Will be addressed in 4.4
Asaf - This is a low priority defect. If you can, pls address this in i3.

I will update the code so that JAVA_PROFILER_HOME will precede BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR in the search order. This will take care of the VTune-related issues. BTW, as far as I know, VTune no longer defines BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR in the system path when it is installed. Therefore, this problem is not likely to happen with newer VTune versions (8.x and above).

I prefer to leave this as-is. The suggested solution to update the code to look for JAVA_PROFILER_HOME before BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR may cause VTune not to work properly in environments were TPTP is already installed. Therefore, I prefer to keep this as a TPTP known issue rather than making it a VTune issue.
Resolving this bug as WONTFIX
I confirm that this problem did not appear for me w/ VTune 8 or with the new VTune 9.

I am not sure what happened but somehow something reset BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR on my laptop so this reappeared for me while I was trying to smoke test 4.4 on my systems. Clearing out BISTRO_INSTALL_DIR again. If it happens again I'll try to figure out whats setting it.
I was unable to run TPTP 4.4 on ONE specific system and this was it.
There may be other Bistro-based tools such as Intel Thread Checker and Intel Thread Profiler which may set this environment variable.

bug.short_desc: NPE in NatureManager.computerNatureEnablement()

long_desc.thetext:
Have seen this exception a couple of times in our test runs. Don't have a repro, but thought the stack trace may be enough to go on...
[exec] java.lang.NullPointerException [exec] at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.NatureManager.computeNatureEnablements(NatureManager.java:50) [exec] at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.NatureManager.getEnabledNatures(NatureManager.java:332) [exec] at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.NatureManager.isNatureEnabled(NatureManager.java:433) [exec] at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Project.isNatureEnabled(Project.java:730)
From inspecting the code, I see how this can happen if the project is deleted or closed concurrently in another thread. I have released a fix. Thanks for reporting this.
Wow! That was quick. We will no be able to verify this since we are not sure of the repro, so I am marking this closed. Thanks for the fix!
*** Bug 167691 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: [Provider] Update IRCLib to v1.10

long_desc.thetext: IRCLib 1.10 approved for distribution. Update ECF IRC provider to use latest version of IRCLib

As part of this, I would like to refactor out the IRClib into its own bundle. If people agree, I would like to call it 'org.eclipse.ecf.irc' or something like that ;)
I've been thinking lately of encouraging ECF and contributors to start "clean-house" implementations of various protocols and incubate them in the ECF project so they can easily be found. By the graciousness of Christoph Schwering, we already have a good start on the IRC one.
What are people's thoughts on this?
Would Christoph approve and would like to maintain IRClib within ECF using Eclipse's facilities?

(In reply to comment #1) > As part of this, I would like to refactor out the IRClib into its own bundle. > If people agree, I would like to call it 'org.eclipse.ecf.irc' or something > like that ;)
Are you planning to Orbit this?
> I've been thinking lately of encouraging ECF and contributors to start > "clean-house" implementations of various protocols
A noble cause, I still have my half-baked MSN implementation from almost a year ago. I'm probably going to do a rewrite from scratch later though since I want to cover the features of the new protocol and also allow it to run on Foundation runtimes.
> and incubate them in the ECF > project so they can easily be found.
I'm not sure I follow here. What is this "can easily be found"?

(In reply to comment #2) > > Are you planning to Orbit this?
There is no reason to Orbit this if the code is actually being maintained in ECF CVS along with bugzilla tracking etc... Orbit is for code outside of Eclipse that needs to be "bundlized"
> A noble cause, I still have my half-baked MSN implementation from almost a year > ago. I'm probably going to do a rewrite from scratch later though since I want > to cover the features of the new protocol and also allow it to run on > Foundation runtimes.
True, I'm a dreamer here, but I think if we at least start somewhere, I think more contributors would be interested. Or we could seek people that have projects out there now and get them to a) license under EPL b) develop it under ECF
This would take some evangelizing though ;)
> I'm not sure I follow here. What is this "can easily be found"?
By easily found I'm saying we would have all the EPL'd protocols out in one place (under ECF). This is probably a less important reason, but my goal is to foster a really healthy community in ECF around protocols ;)
Also Remy, would you be willing to contribute the BT implementation (not the provider) to ECF and have the code developed / tracked using Eclipse facilities (ie., org.eclipse.ecf.bt?)

Hi Chris,
(In reply to comment #1) > As part of this, I would like to refactor out the IRClib into its own bundle. > If people agree, I would like to call it 'org.eclipse.ecf.irc' or something > like that ;)
I have no problem with this in general, but I think it would probably have/should be called org.schwering.irc.lib.
> > I've been thinking lately of encouraging ECF and contributors to start > "clean-house" implementations of various protocols and incubate them in the ECF > project so they can easily be found. By the graciousness of Christoph > Schwering, we already have a good start on the IRC one.
> > What are people's thoughts on this?
I'm more than OK with this general idea (getting 'clean house' impls of various protocols behind ECF), but it's going to take some infusion of resources to ECF to make it actually happen. As project lead I simply can't reasonably commit to being able to doing a number of protocol implementations, along with exemplary apps, along with API design/development, etc., all in parallel. I would like to, don't get me wrong.
> > Would Christoph approve and would like to maintain IRClib within ECF using > Eclipse's facilities?
I think probably so.

Hi Chris,
(In reply to comment #3) > (In reply to comment #2) > > > > Are you planning to Orbit this? > > There is no reason to Orbit this if the code is actually being maintained in > ECF CVS along with bugzilla tracking etc... Orbit is for code outside of > Eclipse that needs to be "bundlized" > > > A noble cause, I still have my half-baked MSN implementation from almost a year > > ago. I'm probably going to do a rewrite from scratch later though since I want > > to cover the features of the new protocol and also allow it to run on > > Foundation runtimes. > > True, I'm a dreamer here, but I think if we at least start somewhere, I think > more contributors would be interested. Or we could seek people that have > projects out there now and get them to a) license under EPL b) develop it under > ECF > > This would take some evangelizing though ;)
You're not kidding about that.
> > > I'm not sure I follow here. What is this "can easily be found"? > > By easily found I'm saying we would have all the EPL'd protocols out in one > place (under ECF). This is probably a less important reason, but my goal is to > foster a really healthy community in ECF around protocols ;)
Yeah!
> > Also Remy, would you be willing to contribute the BT implementation (not the > provider) to ECF and have the code developed / tracked using Eclipse facilities > (ie., org.eclipse.ecf.bt?) >
Not intending to split hairs here, but probably: org.eclipse.ecf.provider.bt. There's already a bug to follow this: #144133

Is it possible to cc Christoph on this bug to see his comments?
I'm willing to do the bundlization once we have approval and willingness from Cristoph.
As for doing clean-room implementations of protocol, isn't it possible to start somewhere at least? Maintain EPL'd providers/protocol implementors in Eclipse CVS, while maintaining others at Oregon that don't meet the license requirements.
In regards to Remy's BT impl, shouldn't it be split into two, the protocol impl along with the provider impl? I would imagine there be two bundles. This would allow people to download simply the protocol impl w/o the ECF specifics.
Thoughts?

(In reply to comment #6) > Is it possible to cc Christoph on this bug to see his comments?
Yeah, I added him with this. Christoph could you please look at this bug thread and see what you think? Thanks.
> > I'm willing to do the bundlization once we have approval and willingness from > Cristoph. > > As for doing clean-room implementations of protocol, isn't it possible to start > somewhere at least? Maintain EPL'd providers/protocol implementors in Eclipse > CVS, while maintaining others at Oregon that don't meet the license > requirements.
Yes. This is what we've been doing, for all intents and purposes. No reason not to continue. But we do need to focus on improving/developing a new exemplary application at this point, prior to 1.0 and Europa. So I've been personally trying to move away from working on providers in favor of improving/adding to the user interfaces. I think we should particularly focus on IRC, IM/chat, and buddy list/roster UI features so that we have really *good* clients for IRC/chat, IM, buddy list.
> > In regards to Remy's BT impl, shouldn't it be split into two, the protocol impl > along with the provider impl? I would imagine there be two bundles. This would > allow people to download simply the protocol impl w/o the ECF specifics. > > Thoughts?
Fine with me. Up to Remy. I only care about ECF filetransfer impl for bittorrent, but no reason not to expose bittorrent directly...modulo the additional work involved in supporting multiple APIs.

> Yeah, I added him with this. Christoph could you please look at this bug > thread and see what you think? Thanks. I've no objections against refactoring Chris's plans. I'd also like to maintain the IRClib bundle within ECF, so that I can easily synchronize the original IRClib with ECF's copy.

(In reply to comment #3) > Or we could seek people that have > projects out there now and get them to a) license under EPL b) develop it under > ECF
Okay, Chris, if I'm reading you right, what you're saying is asking people to (re-/dual-)license their software under the EPL (or does it only need to be EPL-compatible?), and also completely migrate development to occur under the eclipse.org setup, yes? I ask since Christoph's comment #8 with "synchronize" and “copy” seems to imply that development still goes on wherever the project originally was at and the difference now is that they're committing on two repositories. Yuck! Christoph doesn't sound like he minds, but I would mind.
So which is it, or is it something entirely different?
> This would take some evangelizing though ;)
No kidding, if what I think you're saying is correct (migrate to eclipse.org completely as above), you're going to have to give the developers some real good reasons for switching. For starters, they may have to switch RCSes, to CVS, of all things. *shudders*
> Also Remy, would you be willing to contribute the BT implementation (not the > provider) to ECF and have the code developed / tracked using Eclipse facilities > (ie., org.eclipse.ecf.bt?)
I am not a lawyer, does it matter that it's being dual-ed or do I have to use EPL solely? Don't mind if it's the latter but if that is the case I'll probably prepare and release a dual-ed package over at eclipse-incub before switching to EPL completely.
(In reply to comment #5) > Not intending to split hairs here, but probably: org.eclipse.ecf.provider.bt.
At the moment the implementation is named org.eclipse.bittorrent and the provider is named org.eclipse.ecf.provider.bittorrent. Can rename/shorten as necessary.
(In reply to comment #7) > > In regards to Remy's BT impl, shouldn't it be split into two, the protocol impl > > along with the provider impl? I would imagine there be two bundles. This would > > allow people to download simply the protocol impl w/o the ECF specifics. > > > > Thoughts? > > Fine with me. Up to Remy. I only care about ECF filetransfer impl for > bittorrent, but no reason not to expose bittorrent directly...modulo the > additional work involved in supporting multiple APIs.
I think this raises an interesting point with regards to this whole "having-protocol-implementations-under-ECF". Is this, really, the scope of this project? Do we want our bugzilla to start getting filled with bugs like "com.xyz.msn.Client suddenly stopped connecting!" (more often than not this is a server problem)? We've been lucky not to have people file bugs they've found in Jive Software's Smack library since I've started watching those ecf inbox email accounts, but there's nothing saying that this won't ever happen.
In the scenario above, the “additional work” would probably solely revolve around the fact that people are going to go through ECF discussion channels to mouth off their problems with a protocol implementation instead of wherever the project used to be hosted at. At the end of day, the physical work will be done by the person that said “yes, I will move my project to ECF at eclipse.org”. Point being that if it wasn't hosted here and someone filed a bug, the implementor would fidget away and fix it. If it was filed over here, it would still be that person doing the work, except that everyone else watching ecf-core (or another inbox email) is notified and this may displease them because it doesn't really have anything to do with ECF (per se).
Don't get me wrong, I think this is a great idea (putting all EPL'd protocols in one place per comment #3), but I think this is something that's worthy of discussion and analysis. Anyway, we should probably take this to dev.

(In reply to comment #9) > (In reply to comment #3) <stuff deleted> > > Okay, Chris, if I'm reading you right, what you're saying is asking people to > (re-/dual-)license their software under the EPL (or does it only need to be > EPL-compatible?), and also completely migrate development to occur under the > eclipse.org setup, yes? I ask since Christoph's comment #8 with "synchronize" > and “copy” seems to imply that development still goes on wherever > the project originally was at and the difference now is that they're committing > on two repositories. Yuck! Christoph doesn't sound like he minds, but I would > mind.
Christoph is already triple licensing IRCLib under EPL, Apache 2, and LGPL (nothing implied in ordering ;-).
I don't think the expectation would be that Christoph would have to commit to two repositories. The one at sourceforge (or wherever he prefers) would be primary, and all updates to others...e.g. dev.eclipse.org would have to be done off of that one. Unless Christoph wants to move the primary to dev.eclipse.org under ECF project (under EPL, of course)...which he is most welcome to do...but I'm not going to ask him to maintain changes in two locations.
> > So which is it, or is it something entirely different? > > > This would take some evangelizing though ;) > > No kidding, if what I think you're saying is correct (migrate to eclipse.org > completely as above), you're going to have to give the developers some real > good reasons for switching. For starters, they may have to switch RCSes, to > CVS, of all things. *shudders*
:-). Subversion is coming...but will be a while.
> > > Also Remy, would you be willing to contribute the BT implementation (not the > > provider) to ECF and have the code developed / tracked using Eclipse facilities > > (ie., org.eclipse.ecf.bt?) > > I am not a lawyer, does it matter that it's being dual-ed or do I have to use > EPL solely? Don't mind if it's the latter but if that is the case I'll probably > prepare and release a dual-ed package over at eclipse-incub before switching to > EPL completely.
IANAL either, but I think the decision about dualing or single license is up to the copyright holder (you). If it's main home is dev.eclipse.org though it has to be under EPL (at least). Actually, it would probably be best to ask Janet Campbell (EF legal) about dual licensing...I don't think it's a problem for EF, but honestly I'm not sure. email: janet.campbell at eclipse.org. Let me know if you would prefer if I contact her as the ECF project lead and I'll do so.
> > (In reply to comment #5) > > Not intending to split hairs here, but probably: org.eclipse.ecf.provider.bt. > > At the moment the implementation is named org.eclipse.bittorrent and the > provider is named org.eclipse.ecf.provider.bittorrent. Can rename/shorten as > necessary. > > (In reply to comment #7) > > > In regards to Remy's BT impl, shouldn't it be split into two, the protocol impl > > > along with the provider impl? I would imagine there be two bundles. This would > > > allow people to download simply the protocol impl w/o the ECF specifics. > > > > > > Thoughts? > > > > Fine with me. Up to Remy. I only care about ECF filetransfer impl for > > bittorrent, but no reason not to expose bittorrent directly...modulo the > > additional work involved in supporting multiple APIs. > > I think this raises an interesting point with regards to this whole > "having-protocol-implementations-under-ECF". Is this, really, the scope of this > project? Do we want our bugzilla to start getting filled with bugs like > "com.xyz.msn.Client suddenly stopped connecting!" (more often than not this is > a server problem)? We've been lucky not to have people file bugs they've found > in Jive Software's Smack library since I've started watching those ecf inbox > email accounts, but there's nothing saying that this won't ever happen.
I think this is inevitable. Note this problem isn't limited to ECF...in fact I think it's likely to be more accute and immediate for Orbit. It's happened several times recently with Mylar (http client) as well, and I'm sure it's happening with many other Eclipse projects.
So, although I don't deny it's an issue, at least it's not an issue ECF has to face alone :).
> > In the scenario above, the “additional work” would probably solely > revolve around the fact that people are going to go through ECF discussion > channels to mouth off their problems with a protocol implementation instead of > wherever the project used to be hosted at. At the end of day, the physical work > will be done by the person that said “yes, I will move my project to ECF > at eclipse.org”. Point being that if it wasn't hosted here and someone > filed a bug, the implementor would fidget away and fix it. If it was filed over > here, it would still be that person doing the work, except that everyone else > watching ecf-core (or another inbox email) is notified and this may displease > them because it doesn't really have anything to do with ECF (per se).
Yes, all true. But as I said this problem exists more deeply as Eclipse uses more and more third party stuff (like Apache libs, etc). I'm thinking of bringing this up with the committer Board reps as I do think it's likely to be a growing problem (both because it makes more and more sense to use third party libs in Eclipse, and this will certainly be the result).
> > Don't get me wrong, I think this is a great idea (putting all EPL'd protocols > in one place per comment #3), but I think this is something that's worthy of > discussion and analysis. Anyway, we should probably take this to dev. >
Yeah, that would be fine.

(In reply to comment #10) > I don't think the expectation would be that Christoph would have to commit to > two repositories. The one at sourceforge (or wherever he prefers) would be > primary, and all updates to others...e.g. dev.eclipse.org would have to be done > off of that one. Unless Christoph wants to move the primary to dev.eclipse.org > under ECF project (under EPL, of course)...which he is most welcome to do...but > I'm not going to ask him to maintain changes in two locations.
First of all, I'd like to move the primary development to ECF -- as long as I don't have to give up licensing IRClib under Apache 2 and LGPL additionally to EPL.
I'm sorry my word choice was bad in my previous comment. I wouldn't use two repositories at once neither. What I wanted to point out is that, if I'd move IRClib's development to ECF (which I'd like to in general), I want to ensure that it's still licensed under LGPL, Apache 2, too, and I want to ensure that it won't disappear in the deepness of ECF's repository ;).

(In reply to comment #10) > Actually, it would probably be best to ask Janet > Campbell (EF legal) about dual licensing...I don't think it's a problem for EF, > but honestly I'm not sure. email: janet.campbell at eclipse.org. Let me know > if you would prefer if I contact her as the ECF project lead and I'll do so.
I think it'd be better if you do it since I'm kind of a_random_person. Just CC me and Christoph given that he has a tri-licensing requirement wish as outlined in comment #11.
Also, I think [1] is a good read about contributions to a project. That being, even if we move a protocol implementation here, can we really just "randomly" automatically give those developers committer rights? I think you all know what I'm trying to say here, it's a bit hard to put in words right now.
[1] - http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.foundation/msg01353.html

Hi Remy,
(In reply to comment #12) > (In reply to comment #10) > > Actually, it would probably be best to ask Janet > > Campbell (EF legal) about dual licensing...I don't think it's a problem for EF, > > but honestly I'm not sure. email: janet.campbell at eclipse.org. Let me know > > if you would prefer if I contact her as the ECF project lead and I'll do so. > > I think it'd be better if you do it since I'm kind of a_random_person. Just CC > me and Christoph given that he has a tri-licensing requirement wish as outlined > in comment #11.
OK I sent a note to Janet and copied the two of you.
> > Also, I think [1] is a good read about contributions to a project. That being, > even if we move a protocol implementation here, can we really just "randomly" > automatically give those developers committer rights?
No. Like it says in [1], there are contributions and committers and one does not necessarily imply the other. OTOH...for folks that are interested in becoming committers and have already contributed significantly to ECF, as project lead I would have no objection to nominating both Christoph and Remy as committers for ECF. Of course, it's not entirely up to me...i.e. committer vote, Foundation check, etc are also required.
>I think you all know what > I'm trying to say here, it's a bit hard to put in words right now. > > [1] - http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.foundation/msg01353.html >

Well, my point is that, okay, say I license some protocol implementation to EPL so there are no legal problems.
1. I make a bug and say "I contribute this code to ECF". 2. EF queries me during the IPzilla process and all is good. 3. It gets committed to eclipse.org's CVS repository. 4. A day later, I alter my code and says, "okay, this looks good, let's commit it". 5. Oh wait, I am not a committer, I can't do this myself, so I file a bug + patch. 6. Someone from ECF looks at it...and is generally confused because he or she is unfamiliar with my code (a_random_protocol_implementation_01). 7. I cannot update my code now that it's in eclipse.org because I have no committer rights and no committers knows my code enough to say "this looks good and safe".
Okay, or we assume that 6 is void and the guy just says "okay if you think so" and commits it. That is "fine", but 5-6 keeps looping for infinity because I can't commit directly. If I am a freelance person and have wads of free time, this is going to be happen a lot, and is rather ugly.
So how will this scenario be resolved?
assiging to slewis as will be able to do over next few days (12/12/2006)

bug.short_desc: Can't Run/Debug/Profile from source editor context menus

long_desc.thetext:
wtp-sdk-I-I200611300401-200611300401.zip
When editing a JSP within a targetted dynamic web project, choosing Run/Debug/Profile on Server from the editor's context menu fails immediately with a dialog stating "The selection is not within a valid module." It works fine from the file's context menu in the Project Explorer.
I've only seen this in one editor in the past, and it was a bug in the editor. I'll need to reproduce and debug it. Which editor are you using - the JSP source editor?

The bug I was referring to is bug 116217, fixed in 3.2 and above. I tested this in WTP 2.0 and could not reproduce.
Nitin - I was in the JSP source editor, right clicking and selecting Run As > Run on Server, and this works fine for me. Is this what you were doing? Please let me know if you were doing something different or the steps you are taking to reproduce this.

I have also encountered this symptom. On my Linux Laptop I have a WTP 2.0M3 test installation that does this consistently. The cause is that for reasons I have yet to determine, webstatic1 and webstatic2 appear first in the list of moduleArtifactAdapters as displayed by ServerPlugin.loadModuleArtifactAdapters() with tracing enabled. The remaining moduleArtifactAdapters appear in the "usual" order, "ejb", "ear" , "cactus", and "webresource". Because the "cactus" entry is the only one with a priority other than zero, the sort that follows loading swaps the "webstatic1" entry with the "cactus" entry and "webstatic2" remains as the second entry. The criteria for "webstatic2" looks like it will grab most anything in an editor and because it doesn't contain a module, prevents the Run/Debug/Profile from succeeding.
It's unclear to me why this installation has the "webstatic" entries first when many others have them last. I routinely use a "links" directory with "*.link" files under the "eclipse" directory to connect the eclipse installation to the various dependencies. I'm not sure if that approach lends itself to this occurring. I think I have seen this with Windows, but I can't confirm with any of my current Windows Eclipse installations. Given that there appears to be some variability, perhaps the priority setting on the moduleArtifactAdapters could be used to ensure the desired order.

Thanks, Larry - that's exactly what I needed to reproduce the problem and see what the problem is. Looking at the StaticWebDeployableObjectAdapterUtil (impl behind webstatic1 and webstatic2), it's just some logic (checking that the project is a valid static web project) that's missing in the case where the file is adapted from another object. I'll send this the wst.web team and attach a patch that I've tested.
I have confirmed the patch fixes the issue on my Linux Laptop.

Pinging. :)
It would be nice if this could be included in WTP 2.0RC0. I never found a way to "fix" the order of the moduleArtifactAdapters, so users who encounter the odd order won't be able to use this feature.
Hi Raj - another related run-on bug possibly for RC0

Patch looks good - I approve....
We missed RC0 - but we'll get in first thing RC1
Approved.
this was dropped couple days ago
closed

bug.short_desc: [DOC] LinuxPPC64: no longer need root userid to start AC with Security - change Getting_Started

long_desc.thetext:
Originally on LinuxPPC64, if security was enabled during the Agent Controller configuration step, the Agent Controller had to be subsequently started using the root userid. This is no longer true for TPTP 4.2.1.1 and 4.3. Now the root userid password is needed to configure the Agent Controller for security but the root userid is not required for subsequent start of the Agent Controller. The Getting Started doc where this is described needs to be changed.
Specifically, change the first sentence of the last paragraph of the "Configuring and starting Agent Controller" section of the LinuxPPC64 "Getting Started doc"
from: "If you enable security during the configuration step (via SetConfig.sh), currently you need to start the Agent Controller using the root user id. "
to: "If you enable security during the configuration step (via SetConfig.sh), you will be prompted for the root password which is required for one operation in the configuring of security. Thereafter, you start the Agent Controller using any user id."
I have incorporated the requested change.
Fixed

bug.short_desc: Deadlock in SSE (JSPIndexManager Variety)

long_desc.thetext:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #126115 +++
This bug tracks creating a workaround fix for one specific occurrence of the problem tracked by Bug #126115. The thread dump can be found in Comment #28 of Bug #126115.
The first thread is a job that's running with a scheduling rule and attempts to do getModelForRead which blocks because JSPIndexManager is not holding a scheduling rule while calling getModelForRead and the buffer decides to refresh the underlying file.
The suggest workaround for this problem is to make sure to manually call refreshLocal before calling getModelForRead. We'd like to see this workaround implemented in the JSPIndexManager in the 1.5.3 time frame. We have seen this problem several times as this point in our automated tests.

Created an attachment (id=55267) proposed (workspace) patch
This patch adds a refresh call before the getModelForRead() invocation in the JSPSearchDocument.
Konstantin, have you confirmed that the attached patch prevents the deadlock?

Sorry it took so long to get back to you with the test results. I ran the patch half a dozen times through our automated tests and did not see any issues come up. While that in itself is not an indicator as the original problem was intermittent in nature, analysis of the original problem and the patch seems to indicate that the patch does resolve the problem.
Released with David's review.

bug.short_desc: New technology Agent Controller should be moved to the technology preview section

long_desc.thetext: The way our download page is set up for the Agent Controller is a bit confusing. The new download page as described in bug#159331 allows the user to download two different types of Agent Controllers: The "regular" AC and the new technology AC. If the new technology Agent Controller for non-Windows platforms is not ready to replace the old Agent Controller, it should be listed under the technology preview section, not as a separate download for the user. It should only be moved from the technology preview section when it's completely ready to replace the old Agent Controller.

The move out of "tech preview" section was based on whether the new AC technology was ready for general consumption using its new API. You are suggesting that it should remain tech preview until it supports backwards compatibility across all platforms. I don't agree.

I'm suggesting that it should be moved to the technology preview section until it's in a stable condition. Right now, I don't believe that it is stable for non-Windows platforms. If it was, it would replace the old Agent Controller for Linux IA32. In terms of backward compatibility, the old Agent Controller never supported LINUX-EM64T, LINUX-IPF, WINDOWS-EM64T, and WINDOWS-IPF so providing backward compatibility for these platforms shouldn't be a requirement to move it out of the tech preview section. It should, however, provide backward compatibility for Linux IA32.
Please clarify which API you are saying is unstable: new AC using RAC protocol/API or new AC using new AC protocol/API?

New AC using RAC protocol/API because of the fact it wasn't able to replace the RAC on Linux IA32. I don't know enough about the stability of the new AC using new AC protocol/API to comment on it.
I just believe it's confusing for a first-time user to come to the download page and be presented with a list of technology previews along with two different types of Agent Controllers, the "regular" Agent Controller and a "new technology" Agent Controller. If the new Agent Controller is stable enough on the EM64 and IPF platforms then it should be listed for those platforms in the same link as all the other platforms. We should get rid of the Windows IA32 link for the new technology Agent Controller, since it has already replaced the RAC and they're now the same link. The Linux IA32 link for the new technology AC should be moved to the tech preivew section until it's ready to replace the Linux IA32 link for the RAC.

As I said in comment #1, the decision for being tech preview or not is completely UN-related to whether or not the new AC supports the RAC's old protocol/API. It does not belong in the tech preview section.
I have read the new download page and do not see what is confusing about it. The words appear to explain quite clearly everything that someone making a decision about what to download needs to know.

We need to look at the overall download scenarios, and not just focus on AC, although it is clearly an import TP. JVMTI and BtM are in the same boat.
First priority, and first experience has to target an end user that simply wants to use the GA and supported TPTP function. Not cluttered or confused with bells and whistles, just pick load and go... no multiple choice decissions.
A more advanced and experienced user can go to tech previews and get additional or replacement components, and eahc needs to be clear about what it can and can't do, and where it will and won't run.
Our developers need to also have a fast place to get drivers of what they are working on or want, and this should not be mixed in with end user needs.
This can all be simple, and we have nto got it right yet.
In the case of the AC, we have GA function for all the supported platforms. Sometimes new and sometimes old technology. We have under development commited replacements for some platforms, which are at your own risk function butr can be in the tech preview space if well qualified. We also have API and some is supported everywhere and some is scope to certain platforms. This is what consumers care about.

Based on the comments of Karla and Harm, I am not moving the new agent controller links to the tech preview section. The new AC has been taken out of the tech preview section since TPTP 4.1.0. I think it's not a idea to move it back to tech preview.
If you insist on making some changes, please bring this up in the platform project, and get a consensus on how to display the new AC section on the download page. I will take care of the web page changes after a decision is made.
Updated target to match the iteration when this defect was processed

This is a general defect to keep track of our technology preview tools and to evaluate whether they should be dropped or GAed. Currently the technology preview section of our download page is bloated, these tools should be evaluated to see whether they're stable enough to be GAed or whether they should be dropped from the TPTP site.
This defect can continue to be deferred from one release to another. It's just a way to remind PMC/PLs and Architecture Lead to evaluate the technology preview tools.

bug.short_desc: Aperi Install: install aperi on Linux fails with aperi-schema not found

long_desc.thetext:
1. install aperi on Linux root@tpc-d23-int configure]# ./cfgaperi easy
Aperi Storage Manager Configuration
This program will configure Aperi using default values.
Checking Java installation...passed: 1.5.0_09
Ready to configure.
Configuring the agent... ../agent/configuration/setup.properties ../agent/configuration/agent.config ../agent/agent
Configuring derby... ../db/derby ../db/derbystop ../db/aperi-schema ../db/aperi-ij
Configuring the device server... devsvr/configuration/setup.properties devsvr/configuration/tsnmdbparms.properties ../devsvr/devsvr
Configuring the data server... datasvr/configuration/server.config ../datasvr/datasvr
Configuring the gui... ../gui/gui
Generating start script... ../aperi GUID is 0ad02226-4ac0-457f-ad03-d54a11027648 Storing in /home/aperi/guid.txt
Next, the Derby RDBMS will be started and the Aperi schema created. .. Now the schema will be loaded. Running ./aperi-schema ---- Error while configuring. java.io.IOException: java.io.IOException: ./aperi-schema: not found at java.lang.UNIXProcess.<init>(Unknown Source) at java.lang.ProcessImpl.start(Unknown Source) at java.lang.ProcessBuilder.start(Unknown Source) at java.lang.Runtime.exec(Unknown Source) at java.lang.Runtime.exec(Unknown Source) at java.lang.Runtime.exec(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.aperi.configure.ConfigureAperi.runCmd(ConfigureAperi.java:1429) at org.eclipse.aperi.configure.ConfigureAperi.runSilentDatabaseInstall(ConfigureAperi.java:1193) at org.eclipse.aperi.configure.ConfigureAperi.schema(ConfigureAperi.java:1172) at org.eclipse.aperi.configure.ConfigureAperi.run(ConfigureAperi.java:409) at org.eclipse.aperi.configure.ConfigureAperi.configure(ConfigureAperi.java:231) at org.eclipse.aperi.configure.ConfigureAperi.main(ConfigureAperi.java:211) [root@tpc-d23-int configure]#
The file is in <installdir>/db.

Created an attachment (id=54844) the aperi-schema in ../db/aperi-schema
should access ../db/aperi-schema
aperi-schema was trying to

aperi-schema was trying to cd $DERBY_HOME
but DERBY_HOME was not set. On Windows, "cd " stays where you are, but on Unix, "cd " takes you home. So the failure to set DERBY_HOME in this script was not noticed on Windows.
I added the appropriate EXPORT DERBY_HOME=<blah> to the script generator. cfgaperi can now configure aperi & invoke aperi-schema fine.
verified

bug.short_desc: [javadoc] Potentially wrong javadoc warning for unexpected duplicate tag @value

long_desc.thetext: Using (v_725), the contents of the type org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.java.ContentAssistHistory in JDT/UI code reports two javadoc warnings. I would expect none of them.

There must be javadoc warnings in this case as @value is wrongly used on a member which is not a static field (this is the only valid syntax when compliance <= 1.4: see bug 153399)...
The problem here is that we shouldn't complain about duplicate tags, they are all unexpected.

The syntax {@value reference_to_static_field} is only valid since 1.5. Before, the correct syntax for @value is {@value} put in the javadoc comment of the static field. In the case you're talking about, the javadoc is on the constructor => it's not valid and explains why compiler should comply
Yeah, but it is inside <code> an hence I would not expect JDT Core to check stuff inside that one. You people are just too smart ;-)
Not sure though what the JLS says about that but AFAIK it's pretty vague when it comes to Javadoc, so the buest guess is to check what javadoc.exe does.

(In reply to comment #4) > Yeah, but it is inside <code> an hence I would not expect JDT Core to check > stuff inside that one. You people are just too smart ;-) > Thanks a lot ;-)
(In reply to comment #5) > Not sure though what the JLS says about that but AFAIK it's pretty vague when > it comes to Javadoc, so the buest guess is to check what javadoc.exe does. > Even inside <code> tag, javadoc tool 1.4 complain about this syntax: warning - Inline tag {@value} should only be used with a constant field. That was the goal of the bug 153399 fix that JDT compiler warns the same way than javadoc tool on @value tag: SUCCESS :-)

bug.short_desc: Sync Wizard does not sync "replace" variability correctly for configurations that do not contain replacing elements

long_desc.thetext:
The sync wizard allow to synchronize a process against any valid configuration. If the default configuration contains a "replace" for a task, but a second valid configuration does not include the replacing task a sync against the second configuration removes the task from the process instead of recreating the replaced task without its replacement.
(Discussed the solution with Phong. He knows how to fix it.)

If the descriptor is linked to a replacer that is not in the configuration used to sync, but its base is still in this configuration then instead of deleting the descriptor, the tool now links the descriptor to the base element and sync'es on the base.

The 'td01' is added and link to base task 'taskA' 10. Select CP and do sync again -->Problem: 1. Two task descriptor 'taskA' and 'taskB' are added, and both of them are link to 'taskA'

bug.short_desc: how to load the default config.ini when the customed one is not exist

long_desc.thetext:
app user can have its own configurate( a file "config.ini" in the folder ) and set it by the argument "osgi.configuration.area", eclipse framework can read it and load the boot bundles defined by "osgi.bundles", system started --- this is passed in my testcase.
but, the issue is: 1)set osgi.configuration.area = XXX\configuration (BUT there is NO config.ini file in it) 2)set osgi.sharedConfigration.area = default\configuration(there is a default config.ini in it, which can make system started succ). 3)set osgi.configuration.cascaded=true.
under my understanding, if eclipse cannot find the config.ini under XXX\configuration, it will load the default config.ini(defined by sharedConfiguration.area), and system will started succ, but it not.
in class EclipseStarter.loadConfigurationInfo(), it do nothing more after the failure of openStream for the custom config.ini file.
so, what's the correct way when there is no customed config.ini file and make the system load the default one? copy the file manually?
Thanks
What version of eclipse are you using?

We use Eclipse 3.2.x
do you mean if we use the latest version of eclipse, we can load the *parent* config.ini file to start if *child* config.ini does not exist?
Thanks.

It looks like the code in startup.jar does extra processing to load the parent (or shared) config.ini. I can see how this would fail if you are launching Equinox with only the org.eclipse.osgi jar (i.e. java -jar org.eclipse.osgi.jar). If you launch with the startup.jar (or eclipse.exe) then this should work.
This works for me if I place the following in the eclipse.ini and launch with the eclipse.exe
-vmargs -Xms40m -Xmx256m -Dosgi.configuration.area=XXX/configuration -Dosgi.sharedConfiguration.area=default/configuration -Dosgi.configuration.cascaded=true

follow your suggestion, my own RCP should implement the same code in Main(startup.jar) if we use org.eclipse.osgi.jar to start the framework as now, am i right?
and, is it a bug of the osgi.jar?
Thanks.

This is a bug, we should process the config.ini in the osgi.jar the same way we do in startup.jar. We probably need some kind of flag set by startup.jar to indicate to osgi that the config.ini has already been processed so we do not need to reprocess them again in osig.jar.
Instead of copying the code yourself into your RCP application I suggest you just use eclipse.exe and/or startup.jar to launch your application. This is by far the most tested and stable way to launch an RCP application.

As a side note, while it may be a problem, I don't believe the current behaviour is a "bug". If you are not using startup.jar you are responsible for doing the work that it does. In particular, figuring out some of the configuration settings. The need to duplicate the processing code is not currently supported by the usecases. For example, why can't people just use startup.jar?
Having said that, simplification is always good so if we can find a way to simplify things (both in the code and for users) then so much the better.
I'm closing as wontfix. Advanced configurations should use the launcher (startup.jar or the new org.eclipse.equinox.launcher) to launch Equinox.

bug.short_desc: IProject.getFile(name).getName differs

Thanks, your snippet passed without problems.
I found the cause for this behaviour. We use a ZIP-File for importing a project in our test case. This ZIP-File uses backslashes as path seperators and starts with "\" as root. Under Windows no problems, but on the linux build machine.
I will talk to the creator of this ZIP to produce valid files.
So I would suggest to close this bug as INVALID, or should this be checked by the archive import process?
Thanks. Backslash ('\') is a valid character in Unix file names, so we cannot interpret them as path separators on this platform.

bug.short_desc: Don't abort build when CompilationParticipants fix classpath

long_desc.thetext:
A Java build starts by JavaBuilder.initializeBuilder() calling CompilationParticipant.aboutToBuild() for each participant. The purpose of this call is in part for the participant to make sure that it has the resources it needs to build - in particular, to create any output directories it needs.
The build then goes on to call isWorthBuilding(), which calls isClassPathBroken(). But rather than actually checking the classpath, all that does is look at existing markers to see if there are any classpath problems.
If there is a missing directory that is a source path (e.g., the APT generated source folder), then there will be a classpath error marker. Ideally when the participant (APT) creates the missing directory, it would also remove the error marker; but it can't, because the participant has no way of knowing which marker(s) to remove.
So instead what happens is that build is aborted because of the unbound source folder; and then, hopefully, a resource change event triggered by creation of the directory causes a subsequent build to occur.
In practice, that resource event seems a bit unreliable. We are encountering situations where the change event does not seem to be getting noticed, or if it is getting noticed it is getting thrown away again, possibly because there are conflicting jobs in the queue at the same time.
So we would like a more reliable approach. I think a good approach would be, if isClasspathBroken() returns true, to actually validate the classpath again before aborting the build.
I have tested this approach and it does fix some nasty bugs we're fighting. However, I don't know whether I've done it the most efficient or correct way. I'll attach the patch that I've been using as a sample.

Created an attachment (id=54867) suggested patch for 3.2.1
Here's the patch I've been testing on 3.2.1. It won't work on 3.3 because JavaProject methods have changed; my test scenario involves a lot of WTP plug-ins so I can't test on 3.3 yet, so I'm not sure how this should be done on 3.3.
Any chance of getting this in for M7?

Jerome - updateClasspathMarkers() was removed.
Is there another way we can force the classpath markers to be recomputed?
I thought the resolution of this bug was make the APT generated source folder optional (see IClasspathAttribute#OPTIONAL)
If the optional tag doesn't do the trick, let us know.

The optional tag does indeed fix the problem for APT, thanks!
Other compilation participants might not know how to fix this though. Two options I can think of to deal with this:
1) add a call to update the classpath in case a participant fixes it, or 2) document in the compilation participant API that they can use the optional tag on a classpath entry if they run into this case (a folder they create for generated files)
APT is fine with #2, since that's what we're doing. It's also easier. ;)
I'll update the spec to indicate that additional source folders should be tagged as optional.

Updated the spec.
Released for 3.3M7
Verified for 3.3M7

bug.short_desc: [refactoring] source excludes are not updated during 'rename package'

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2.0 M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. take class from package and use 'Build Path->Exclude' to exclude class from build. 2. rename package containing excluded class 3. see that in renamed package (result of refactoring) class won't be excluded.
More information:
Move to JDT/UI

Two reason why we haven't gone into that direction: - Inclusion and exclusion patterns are an advanced feature that can create great confusion if used without knowing what you're doing. - The pattern syntax is quite powerful and complex. Wildcards is one thing and the interaction between inclusion and exclusion patterns the other.
For these reasons I rather let the expert user to configure the rules that trying to guess what rules mean and how rules should be transformed on refactorings.

bug.short_desc: legend anchor does not work

long_desc.thetext:
I cannot left align legend within pie chart. Regardless the chart size and legend's anchor property value the legend is right-aligned. I tried to modify align property in Chart Editor / Chart Format / Legend / Layout, but there is no change between setting this value to East or West.
I want to display plot and then legend, just besides the pie, without any space. So I set the position to "right". Then I there is another property Align, which has possible values North, East, West, South etc. If I set it to North, the legend is rendered in upper right corner. If I set it to south, the legend is positioned in lower right corner. If I set it to east, it is placed to middle right position. This is expected behaviour. But if I set it to west, it is still rendered on right-most horizontal position, it behaves identically as east. I expect, that it will be rendered in left-most position, just besides plot.
I don't understand why is there such space between plot area and legend area. I need to get rid off it. See attachments
Created an attachment (id=54872) pie chart
Created an attachment (id=54873) sample rptdesign

The anchor direction only affects the layout of the content in the area, but not the area itself. In current implementation, the size and layout of legend area are limitted and cannot be customed. Maybe we can enhance this part in the future.
We need to at least fix the empty space problem in RC0
Adjust legend size and postion computing.Remove the space between plot and legend.
That's absolutely awesome! Great, I am looking forward when I will see it in the product! Can you please post me a patch, so we can update our 2.1.2 installation?

You can update the following file directly from CVS:
/org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine/src/org/eclipse/birt/chart/internal/layout/LayoutManager.java
This file was never changed since 2.1, so you can update it from head safely.

bug.short_desc: [quick fix] [quick assist] provide 'exclude from build' as quickfix

long_desc.thetext: In case of 'The type xxx.yyy.Zzz cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files' problem, please, add 'exclude from build' option as a quick fix in addition to 'Configure build path...'
Moving to JDT/UI
What exactly would be excluded?

file/source code causing problems. If there's source code for 'aaa.bbb.Ccc' (aaa/bbb/Ccc.java) referencing class 'foo.bar.Cla' (available in classpath) and class 'foo.bar.Cla' referencing 'xxx.yyy.Zzz' then eclipse will provide 'The type xxx.yyy.Zzz cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files' error in 'problems' view, pointing to 'aaa/bbb/Ccc.java' and as a quick fix providing 'Configure build path...' option (so ideally user should add jar file containing xxx/yyy/Zzz.class). And I think it will be good to have as another option 'Exclude from build' option so 'aaa/bbb/Ccc.java' will not be compiled - exactly the same behavior as available using 'Build Path->Exclude' option for source code files using 'Package Explorer' view.

As mentioned in the other bug, I think inclusion and exclusion patterns are an expert feature that should not be added too quickly. So I think a quick fix would send the wrong message. I don't think it is really a solution to the described problem, you'll run into it with some other classes again.

bug.short_desc: FileLocation line number computation is very slow

long_desc.thetext: Line numbers are computed by counting all '\n' up to the node offset. This does not scale well. I propose to implement a cache based lookup, ie. upon first request, the buffer is scanned for '\n' and all line start offsets are collected. Subsequent requests can be answered using a binary search on the cached information.

bug.short_desc: Copying files across systems should preserve permissions if possible

long_desc.thetext:
When a file is copied from system A to system B, permission bits are not copied, unless both systems support TAR archives and "supertransfer" is activated.
In order to support permission bits for such copy, either - APIs need to be added to read / set permission bits and other extended attributes (does not seem practical), or - APIs need to be added to support supertransfer through archives in a more transparent manner. I think the best solution would be that - Each system type registers the kinds of supertransfer that it supports - During Copy, a "handshake" is done between source and target in order to come up with a common kind of supertransfer that both support - If a common supertransfer is found, permissions can be retained. This proposal is covered in bug 165890.

We found problems with trying to preserve too many permissions (ACLs, Ownership) on Windows Vista, so we decided to not have RSE play he administrator game for now -- admins will likely prefer a commandline anyways. See bug 181667 comment 7 for details.
Some file properties like "Read Only", "Modification Time", should be preserved though. This could work great through EFS if generic properties were supported as suggested by bug 176051: the intersection of the properties supported for reading by the source filesystem and the properties supported for writing by the target file system should be copied.

bug.short_desc: Persistence Test Suite (creation) should not create connections with existing names

long_desc.thetext:
With org.eclipse.rse.tests and org.eclipse.rse.tests.framework installed, do: Window > Show View > Other > RSE Testing Select the "Persistence Test Suite (creation)" test and run it --> 6 connections are created Run the same suite again --> More connections with the same name are created
This is an incosistent state that the system could usually never be in. Thus it should be avoided. Moreover, running the test suite multiple times will allow creating more than 6 hosts if the names are different.
I'd suggest that whenever the alias "TestHost{n}" already exists, the suite should try creating "TestHost{n+1}" instead.
Fixing this soon would be good, since it would allow for easier testing of other bugs, like bug 166156
Bulk update target milestone 2.0.1 -> 3.0

bug.short_desc: [Live download stats] Pulling JAR downloads from Apache logs no longer viable

long_desc.thetext:
Because the Live download stats work with the "Find a mirror" script, and because Update Manager doesn't really use said script, a while back I was asked to populate the downloads database with the JAR downloads from the raw Apache log files. This enabled teams to run download stats for their downloads via UM.
However, it has several flaws:
a) when using mirrors via mirrorsURL, it's not accurate as we can't track the downloads to mirrors. This leads to b)
b) some projects don't use mirrors at all, claiming download stats are more important. This costs the Foundation money, as bandwidth isn't cheap.
c) pulling from the Apache logs is CPU and disk intensive, and most of the four servers spend 6-12 *hours* a day hammering on our MySQL database. Eclipse.org doesn't really have a quiet period during the week, so this is guaranteed to inconvenience someone.
d) roughly 1 million rows are added each day, and the downloads database and its matching indexes have since grown to 31 GB
e) running download queries is CPU and disk intensive, not to mention somewhat slow, from the sheer size of the database
As people have started noticing performance degradation of the eclipse.org infrastructure [1], the time has come to cut some fat.
[1] http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/cross-project-issues-dev/msg00745.html

Maybe it's time to move away from the "live" solution into a "pre-aggregated" approach.
For example, logs could be pulled from Apache every 12 hours and analyzed offline by an external server (a cheap machine). The external server will not create rows for each access but could create an aggregated row for a certain timespan (eg. 10 minutes). There could be even additional aggregation steps which would collapse older stats further.
Then there could be a BIRT based reporting solution to generate some reports in advance and custom reports using a "fire and get it mailed to me when it's done" approach.
Of course, the downside of this would be that you have to wait till tomorrow if you want the stats from today. But that delay can be reduced if you throw in more servers for aggregation. ;)

(In reply to comment #2) > Maybe it's time to move away from the "live" solution into a "pre-aggregated" > approach.
This won't solve the problem where projects are trading accurate stats for performance by choosing to *not* use mirrors (costing us bandwidth).
> For example, logs could be pulled from Apache every 12 hours and analyzed > offline by an external server (a cheap machine).
Lines of logs for download.eclipse.org for 24-hour period of Nov. 30: 734914 ./node1/access_log.1 123 MB 1810227 ./node2/access_log.1 301 MB 1226946 ./node3/access_log.1 204 MB 372711 ./node4/access_log.1 62 MB
That's a fair amount of stuff to process for a cheap machine; also, I'm just about out of rackspace, so I'd need money to implement this. If I could "throw in more servers" I'd simply add them to the eclipse.org infrastructure and we wouldn't be here ;-)
How about this: we already run Webalizer on all our Apache logs. Here's the URL for download.eclipse.org November: https://dev.eclipse.org/committers/webstats/download.eclipse.org/usage_200611.php
How about we increase the number of URLs to, say, 3000 instead of 400, then folks could simply lookup their files? They won't all be displayed, but such is life. This idea won't solve the problem where projects are trading stats for performance by choosing to *not* use mirrors (costing us bandwidth), but it will cut the CPU and Disk time for putting logs into MySQL. Live download stats would continue to work for files that use the Find A Mirror script (download.php?file=...)
The more I read comment 4 the more I think it makes sense. It has file totals, search terms, country aggregates, entry/exit pages, pretty graphs...

Since Eclipse 3.3, download.eclipse.org is listed dead last in the list of mirrors, which has caused our server to only serve about 13 million jar files per month (from 25+ million). This means smaller log files and many fewer records are being inserted by the log scanner.
My next question is: is it really worth scanning download.eclipse.org's log files for JARs that were downloaded directly? I mean, suppose download.eclipse.org served 20 JAR files named 'X'. What does that even mean? 20 people scrolled to the bottom of the mirrors list and picked download.eclipse.org. It in no way represents how many total downloads were fetched from mirrors.
So .. I'm discontinuing feeding the database with JAR files downloaded directly. The number means absolutely nothing anyway, and the alternative is to use the 'find a mirror with automatic redirect' in site.xml for accurate download stats.

After some tests I can deduce that in one SWT application under Windows XP professional, you get a "No more handles" SWT error when you try to show :
9968 Buttons or 9968 Texts or 9968 Labels or 3328 Combos (with or not item in the list or 9968 Composites or 3328 Spinners or 3328 Tables

How does work other applications where there are lot of data/fields to manage ? What I can improve to succeed handle all my fields ?

bug.short_desc: [Progress] Random shells come to the front when compare editor shows progress dialog

long_desc.thetext:
[I20061128-0800]
Sometimes, when opening a compare editor from the sync view, other random shells (e.g. Firefox, Notes...) come to the front. This seems to be related to showing progress in a dialog. It does not happen if the compare results are displayed fast enough.
*** Bug 168516 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 163078 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Boris and I tracked this down to the ProgressManager. The problem is that the Jobs progress monitor stays open after the job finished. The compare code then calls IProgressServive#busyCursorWhile which causes shell deactivation. This hits an SWT workaround which throws focus to an OS shell. I'm pasting the stack since I'm sure we'll forget all this by the time we get back from holidays.

Mine! I have a hack/fix for this.

Fixed > 20070201
Boris, I expect to go through a round of touch ups on this one. Cross your fingers.
Wait. !#$%!@$#% Eclipse.org is down and won't accept my code.
Now it's in.
See bug 172888 for the first of the fallout.
*** Bug 35768 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I'm still seeing this problem in 3.3.1.1.

> I expect to go through a round of touch ups on this one.
Ok, a touch up. Does a random shell from another application come to the front or is it an Eclipse window?

> Ok, a touch up. Does a random shell from another application come to the front > or is it an Eclipse window?
I was using something based on eclipse, and Lotus Notes V7 came to front.

You were using something based on Eclipse 3.3.1.1 and another application (Notes V7) came to the front. The bug that we fixed happened when Windows chooses the next shell to bring to the front:
/* * Feature in Windows. When the active shell is disposed * or hidden, Windows normally makes the parent shell active * and assigns focus. This does not happen when the parent * shell is disabled. Instead, Windows assigns focus to the * next shell on the desktop (possibly a shell in another * application). The fix is to activate the disabled parent * shell before disposing or hiding the active shell. */
We have attempted to work around the scenario and must be missing a case. It is also possible that your application is calling Shell.forceActive() (which calls the win32 API SetForegroundWindow() and this is forcing the window to the top).
Need more to go on to debug this. Can you get a reproducable case?

bug.short_desc: Ant outline reorders steps within target

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: Build id: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Open a non-trivial ant build script. 2. Expand target with several tasks (steps). 3. Click "Sort" button, several times
The tasks witin the target are sorted alphabetically.
As the order of the tasks has semantics, displaying them in a different order as executed is misleading.
Proposal: sort targets and other toplevel elements, but _do not_ reorder targets within a task.
Not really a proposal, might be to expensive: for each XML element, decide if the order of children has semantics, and sort accordingly, or do not sort.
For example, from the semantics of the tasks follows statically: children of javac of different type like classpath and src could be sorted. elements in path cannot.

Thank you for the bug report.
Not currently planned for 3.3
