bug.short_desc: "Default context" capture

long_desc.thetext:
I noticed that a user can un-select the current context such that no context is selected, and can open files. It might be handy to have this as a "scratch / default" context where a user can use it to quickly view files and look at another context (basically make it a task that doesn't show up in the Task List, can't be explicitly selected, and has no description, due date, etc.). As it stands right now the files open in when no context is selected are closed when a context is subsequently selected (which can be frustrating when you forget). This might also be handy for new users as well so they aren't in shock and confusion when they switch to a context for the first time and all of the files they have open are suddenly closed.
In addition, this could be useful so users could copy the default context to a new context if they forget to create a context before they start their work.
Thanks, Jim
There is an issue for this already. See bug 146125

Jim: please make sure that your use case is clearly described on the bug that Eugene is referring to?
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 146125 ***

Thanks for asking me to look at it again Mik. After looking at it again, it may not really be a duplicate, and is much simpler in nature.
The use case I'm thinking of is as follows: 1. User opens up a file while no context is selected. The file is added to the "default context" context. 2. User selects a context and it is loaded. 3. User un-selects the previously selected context and the files are unloaded, the files for the "default context" are then reloaded.
I think that about covers it.
Thanks, Jim
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 146125 ***

bug.short_desc: Projects Java Build Path screen

long_desc.thetext:
After an upgrade or fresh install of Eclipse the plugin jar filenames have changed, this means you have to go to each Project's Properities->Java Build Path screen and reselect the correct jar filenames in the plugins directory.
Would like a button on the Project's Properities->Java Build Path that would scan the plugins directory and update each jar file listed to the latest version.

JDT/UI owns the Java Build Path property page. Not sure why the bug was moved here.
In any event, if you use the ECLIPSE_HOME variable in your library paths, then you wouldn't need to change the paths every time you upgrade.

(In reply to comment #1) > JDT/UI owns the Java Build Path property page. Not sure why the bug was moved > here. > In any event, if you use the ECLIPSE_HOME variable in your library paths, then > you wouldn't need to change the paths every time you upgrade.
Sorry, I did not make myself clear. It is not the path, I use ECLIPSE_HOME, but the filenames that change from release to release of eclipse. A filename in one release may be ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86_3.3.0.v3309.jar and the next release would be ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86_3.3.0.v3314.jar Seems to me that if the program used everything up to the underscore as a pattern to look for and then take the latest version found.

Wouldn't it be better to use the PDE container that does that all for you? I moved it to PDE as I asumed they would tell you that.
I don't think the Java build path page should perform any automatic updating nor should it implement any heuristic that guesses how jar names evolve with growing versions.

bug.short_desc: Search spiders and crawlers contributing to slow Bugzilla performance

long_desc.thetext:
All kinds of crawlers and indexers pound on Bugzilla all day long. This helps contribute to an overall slow bugzilla.
The folks at Mozilla have been quite strict in *not* allowing spiders to crawl their bugzilla installation: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=187870
As people constantly complain about our slow bugzilla installation [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] and the list goes on, I suggest we do the same.
[1] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=153818 [2] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=85960 [3] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=117344 [4] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=162820 [5] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=165005 [6] http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse-dev/msg02278.html [7] http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse-dev/msg06560.html [8] http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/cross-project-issues-dev/msg00745.html
Wow: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=187870#c3

Created an attachment (id=58384) Load average of one DB server
I silently "disallowed" spider crawling of Bugzilla after opening this bug, and average server load has definitely gone down since december.

Closing as fixed. Bugzilla performance is very important for our committers, and disabling spiders has done nothing but good in that respect.
To echo comments from Mozilla, indexing hundreds of thousands of bugs is simply consumes too many resources.

For documentation's sake, I received a request to remove sensitive data from an attachment that contained a product key in a preferences dump. Weeks after removing the data, Google cache still has the stale data, and getting them to remove it has proven difficult (tools for removing URL don't support https yet)

bug.short_desc: Java System Properties specified in command line are not visible in my eclipse session

long_desc.thetext:
I'm using Windows Vista Ultimate and 3.3 integration build I20061129-1340. On my command line I set some java properties: -Duser.tests=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\v33 -Duser.junit=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\JUnit\v33
However, when I try to get them for example while setting location of my JUnit test in launch configuration using 'Variables' button, then I cannot see these properties...
I'll attach whole 'Configuration Details' I get from the "About Eclipse SDK" dialog.

Created an attachment (id=54891) Configuration Details
You can see the system properties definition in the command line but cannot see them in the displayed map below...
VM arguments must be passed on commandline using the -vmargs option. Note that this will override the -vmargs from the eclipse.ini.

I already use -vmargs in my command line as this same batch I use on my Thinkpad with WinXP and it works. It sounds to be a specific issue with Vista as the same command line: start eclipse.exe -showlocation -debug -data D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\dvpt\common\head -vm d:\a\JDKs\sun\1.4.2\jre\bin\java -showversion -verify -vmargs -Xmx512m -Xms128m -Duser.tests=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\v33 -Duser.junit=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\JUnit\v33

Created an attachment (id=54895) Win XP Configuration Details
Note the same System Properties definition in this configuration(as specified in command line): -Duser.tests=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\v33 -Duser.junit=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\JUnit\v33
And below the corresponding entries in System Properties map: ... user.junit=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\JUnit\v33 ... user.tests=D:\usr\OTI\workspaces\tests\v33 ...
In that case this seems like a launcher issue. Andrew do you have any ideas?

It does seem to be a problem in the launcher.
Notice the eclipse.vmargs property in both of the details. The XP property is correct, the Vista one appears to be the contents of the ini file.
As well, the eclipse.commands property in vista has the -D arguments (These should be in the eclipse.vmargs property).
It seems to me something is going wrong while parsing the command line under vista. We are somehow missing the -vmargs there (which means we use the ones from the ini file).
Any chance this is fixed in the new launcher?
I can't reproduce this problem with I20070110 on Vista Enterprise. -D options passed from the command line are passed through correctly to the VM.
Should this be closed as FIXED for 3.3 M5? Do we want a fix for the 3.2 stream?
Finally close as INVALID. I verified it works with Windows Vista build 6000 both for 3.3 and 3.2.1... So, it seems it was a Vista bug (fixed with last version) more than an eclipse one.

bug.short_desc: WSDM Enable Log4j Service

long_desc.thetext: Enable the logging component to be managed via WSDM.

Are there requirements what and how should be exposed through WSDM?
As I looked into Log4j what can be set up, it seems that we could 1. expose a property for reading / setting log level for root logger (property) 2. list of active loggers (read only property) 3. get/set log level for a specific logger (seems like a capability ???) 4. stopping Log4j
5*. getting / setting and modifying properties of appenders; don't know it it is possible - each appender type has different set of properties; can we model it somehow with WSDM??
One more thing might be useful - what about providing a new appender that sends log entries through WS-Notification?

Marcin,
I'm not sure we should focus so closely on Log4J. Would it make more sense to take on logging in general?
I'm thinking that the Corona logging service would be our target. What we probably want is some way to start and stop the logging service itself, track all of the bundles that register with the logging service (these would be seperate manageable resources - perhaps grouped in a service group), change the logging level on a per-bundle basis, and to do a head/tail - type display of the bundle's log. It would also be cool if we could provide a way to do what the .options settings do for tracing, but that may be a stretch goal as I'm not sure that you can change those settings dynamically.
The first thing I'd like to do is get this working as a console extension, and then WSDM-ize it.

Created an attachment (id=56355) Example of console extension, WSDM implementation
Marcin,
The attachment has an example of a console extension. Look at the activator and the ConsoleExtension (cleverly named, I know) to see how to implement a console extension.
Cheers, Joel
Pretty long discussion about logging: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/corona-dev/msg00668.html

bug.short_desc: RCP Delta pack is really an SDK Delta pack ?

long_desc.thetext:
I'm not sure if this is a problem or not.
But the RCP delta pack is apparently built from the SDK feature. That is, it includes all the platform dependent fragments instead of just the RCP fragments.
If someone builds a target with RCP + delta pack, they will have fragments whose host does not exist.
I don't think this is a real problem, and the idea of multiple delta packs is not appealing.
Perhaps we should just drop the RCP and call it just Delta pack? And give it a section on the download page separate from RCP SDK?
Or, just leave things as they are.
*** Bug 186615 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Version ranges on fragment constraints can cause inconsistentcies

long_desc.thetext:
See bug 165377 comment 6
Currently the resolver flags an inconsistentcy if a fragment adds a constraint with a version range that is a subset of an existing constraint version range on the host. In other words the host's constraint version range must be included in the fragment's constraint version range.
This simplifies the resolver because in this case we can simply drop the fragments constraint because we can guarantee if the hosts constraint is resolved then it will satisfy the fragments constraint. We could enhance the resolver to be more lenient in this case and detach fragments if their constraints are not resolved to the final constraint picked by the host bundle when it was resolved.

Created an attachment (id=55139) patch
This patch checks fragment constraints after the host constraints have been resolved. This allows us to check that the final supplier selected by the host satisfies the fragment constraint.
Fixed for M4.
